data.text:
@OYCar Or maybe vaccines work?

And if it was delta you'd have 5x the IFR.

This isn't debated any more, we know Omi is inherently about 70% less virulent than delta. This has been confirmed all over the world now.

Yes it can still kill naive 70+, just less often than delta.

@OYCar @Chrisbilbo We could be seeing more deaths because there has been more infections. And that could be because either the new variant spread more easily, or because previous public health measures failed.

@OYCar They are (obviously) still plenty behind on cumulative death rates. It's possible that Omicron is both milder as well as still dangerous enough to kill an older vulnerable immunonaive age cohort. https://t.co/Xhwv2fc0XM
@NobodyImpawtant Yes many pointed out this important issue but not many listened. Another point some noted was survivorship bias. (@tomtom_m  in particular springs to mind here).
@OYCar Interesting. This data was produced  in December that seemed to be omitted on a significant scale. https://t.co/xqJwOJsGHA
@NobodyImpawtant This is just wrong. In fact the human immune system had adapted to the virus not vice versus.

@NobodyImpawtant Not the ones quoted here. 
"The predictions we made at the start of December still hold. Omicron was less severe. Dramatically. The virus is evolving to adapt to the human host, to become like a seasonal virus," said Prof Marta Nunes,
@OYCar I could be wrong but wasnâ€™t it  because western nations decided to ignore the caveat of some (minor) prior infection immunity from covid?
